xxl.core.collections.containers.io
Class ConverterContainer

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      xxl.core.collections.containers.ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
          xxl.core.collections.containers.io.ConverterContainer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Container
public class ConverterContainer
extends ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

This class provides a container that stores a set of converted elements. The container decorates an underlying container that must be able to store byte arrays (as blocks).

When storing an element in this converter it is converted and the resulting byte array is wrapped by a block. Thereafter this block is stored in the decorated container.

By using a ConverterContainer it is possible to decorate a container that is based on extenal memory, because conversions between objects and byte arrays will be internally done.

Example usage (1). 

     // create a new coverter container with ...

     ConverterContainer container = new ConverterContainer(

         // a map container that stores the elements

         new MapContainer(),

         // an integer converter for converting the elements

         IntegerConverter.DEFAULT_INSTANCE
     );

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Iterator iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     iterator = container.insertAll(iterator);

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(container.get(iterator.next()));

     // get the ids of the elements of the container

     iterator = container.ids();

     // remove 5 elements

     for (int i = 0; i < 5 && iterator.hasNext(); i++) {
         container.remove(iterator.next());

         // refresh the iterator (cause it can be in an invalid state)

         iterator = container.ids();
     }

     // update 5 elements

     for (int i = 0; i < 5 && iterator.hasNext(); i++) {
         Object id = iterator.next();
         container.update(id, new Integer(((Integer)container.get(id)).intValue()+100));
     }

     // get the ids of all elements of the container

     iterator = container.ids();

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(container.get(iterator.next()));

     // close the open queue after use

     container.close();

See Also:
ByteArrayInputStream, ConstrainedDecoratorContainer, Container, DataInputStream, Function, IOException, NoSuchElementException, WrappingRuntimeException

Field Detail

converter

protected Converter converter
The converter that is used for converting the elements of the underlying container.

Constructor Detail

ConverterContainer

public ConverterContainer(Container container,
                          Converter converter)
Constructs a new ConverterContainer that decorates the specified container and uses the specified converter for converting its elements.

Parameters:
container - the underlying container that is used for storing the converted elements.
converter - the converter that is used for converting the elements of this container.
Method Detail

get

public Object get(Object id,
                  boolean unfix)
           throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired object is not found via contains.
This implementation gets the block associated to the id from the underlying container and tries to convert the wrapped byte array. The parameter unfix is passed to the underlying container.

Specified by:
get in interface Container
Overrides:
get in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

insert

public Object insert(Object object,
                     boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object.
This implementation tries to convert the object and inserts a block wrapping the resulting byte array into the underlying container. The parameter unfix is passed to the decorated container. Thereafter the identifier that has been associated to the block by the underlying container is returned.

Specified by:
insert in interface Container
Overrides:
insert in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

objectIdConverter

public FixedSizeConverter objectIdConverter()
Returns a converter for the ids generated by this container. A converter transforms an object to its byte representation and vice versa - also known as serialization in Java.
Since the identifier may have an arbitrary type (which has to be known in the container), the container has to provide such a method when the data is not stored in main memory.

Specified by:
objectIdConverter in interface Container
Overrides:
objectIdConverter in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Returns:
a converter for serializing the identifiers of the container.

getIdSize

public int getIdSize()
Returns the size of the ids generated by this container in bytes. This call is forwarded to the underlying Container.

Specified by:
getIdSize in interface Container
Overrides:
getIdSize in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Returns:
the size in bytes of each id.

reserve

public Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject. This implementation wraps the function getObject by converting the object when invoking the function.

Specified by:
reserve in interface Container
Overrides:
reserve in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:
the reserved id.

update

public void update(Object id,
                   Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container (checked via isUsed).
This implementation tries to convert the object and updates the existing element of the underlying container by a block wrapping the resulting byte array. The parameter unfix is passed to the decorated container.

Specified by:
update in interface Container
Overrides:
update in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the element.
object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals a buffered container whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a ConverterContainer. It can also be used to test the functionality of a ConverterContainer.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
